Unless me, you and everyone else even who have liked the post and comments/ed can "walk the talk", nothing is going to change. Irony is in India CIVICS is taught but not the "civic sense". It is someone else's responsibility. Just look around. My comment might ruffle many feathers but till India moves as a collective not much will change. 

One gets snickered at when asks "where is the trash can?" If one asks for a trash can in most the hotels (even the best) trash cans are out of sight. Folks drive Audi, Mercedes, BMW and other fancy cars but roll down the window to throw trash. Their CIVIC sense is just amazing. Like to teach but cannot live with their own teachings.

Headline: CEO Bahaar Foundation I Livelihoods I Health I Nutrition
Comment:
Came back from my first trip to Japan two days ago with an enormous appreciation for Japan and its people .. completely agree with everything you said Rishabh Mariwala .. it was amazing and liberating and uplifting and joyful ... loved seeing all the kids going to and from school on their own, riding the subway/ bus .. one can actually feel at peace even during a subway ride during rush hour in Tokyo:) 

You may have noticed that there are very few trash cans in public spaces in Japan - people just manage their own trash! Reminds me of some conversations I have had about litter in Indian cities which are promptly blames on the MCD (not enough trash cans, not enough pick up vans, etc etc); we completely ignore our personal responsibility and always making it someone else's problem to address, preferring to look the other way instead of simply not littering the very places we step through also üòì

Rishabh I return to Japan not just for the beauty or the precision, but for the quiet ways in which the country reveals itself..subtle gestures, soft rituals, unspoken codes of respect. Wrote about it:

The Cashier and the Code

Some truths don‚Äôt arrive with thunder; 
They arrive in steam rising from a bowl, 
In the silence between a gesture and a glance.
Some days, you don‚Äôt plan on witnessing grace
You simply stumble into it, hungry, tired, and entirely unprepared.
And yet, it stays with you longer than the meal itself.

Headline: A curious learner | Professionally - Head Finance: Digital Business | Exp. of 10yrs in Retail, E-commerce & FMCG | CA (AIR) | CS | ACCA | DISA
Comment:
Echoing your thoughts completely, I had the chance to travel to Japan last year and was deeply moved by the same values you‚Äôve captured so beautifully. The warmth and hospitality of the people stayed with me. There were several moments where strangers went out of their way to help us, with such grace and humility.
One memory that stands out was an elderly taxi driver,would be close to 80, not only dropped us near the station but actually parked his cab, got out and walked us all the way inside to make sure we found the right way. No words needed; just kindness in action.
Coming back, I found myself thinking along the same lines as to how can we bring this spirit into our lives here? For me, it starts with being more mindful in the everyday, respecting people‚Äôs time and leading with empathy. Small shifts, but powerful when done collectively.

Headline: Go-to expert in the audio industry | Strategic Marketing & Product Development Expert | Global Sourcing Specialist |Electronics Industry Leader
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala there is so much to learn from them. And the difference that I see is "the mindset". This is the only change that we have to bring from 'I/Me to Us/We. Things are changing in our country also though the pace is slow but the direction is correct. A faster change can happen by catching the next generation young while they are still in school.

For instance, a few years ago, I once even wrote to the policy makers on why not make driving license classes mandatory for students from class 10th. They anyways drive while in school or once just out of the high school. Bring this change let them pass the driving lessons and also the exam to get their license.
 What do you say... Will it be a step towards better traffic sense which is one of things that I feel we must learn from these countries.

Headline: Senior Vice President Manufacturing | Bachelor of Engineering, Team Management
Comment:
Thanks for sharing, Rishabh,
Each word speak volumes of the culture.
Undoubtedly you will fall in love with Japan upon visiting it.
I am still awestruck after a decade of visit to that country.
But then:
1) A population of meager 0.1245 billion v/s a humongous 1.4 billion.
2) Children are taught the sense of cleanliness right during school days.
How many us will allow our children to sweep roads and neighhood.
3) Punctuality is taught while still in the cradle.
Don't we frown out loud when our child is punished for being late.
We brag on not being on time, curse the government on not getting the things done.
We oppose all the laws made, industries flout regulations left, right and centre.
It's for us to make the change, make a beginning, kick start a revolution.
Each one of us need to be an agent of change and ask ourselves the next time, we in our individual or professional capacity, mock and scoff the rules in place which we generously do at our convenience for our personal and professional benifit.
Coworker first, neighbour first, society first, country first must be engraved while we are young.
A huge collective responsibility, vigour, determination is needed at each step of citizenship to reach somewhere near Japan
